en.purpose: To calculate and assess the early signs of deterioration in patients by calculating the NEWS score.
en.use:
The NEWS can be used on all hospitalized patients to allow for the early detection of clinical deterioration and potential need for higher level of care.

The score is based on seven parameters, each contributing points to the total score:
- Heart rate - 0p for 51-90, 1p for 41-50/91-110, 2p for 111-130 and 3p for ≤40/≥131
- Systolic blood pressure - 0p for 111-219, 1p for 101-110, 2p for 91-100 and 3p for ≤90/≥220
- Oxygen therapy - 2p for use of supplemental oxygen
- Saturation (SaO2) - 0p for ≥96, 1p for 94-95, 2p for 92-93 and 3p for ≤91
- AVPU - 0p for A, 3p for either V, P or U
- Body temperature - 0p for 36.1-38.0, 1p for 35.1-36.0/38.1-39.0, 2p for ≥39.1 and 3p for ≤35.0
- Respiration rate - 0p for 12-20, 1p for 9-11, 2p for 21-24 and 3p for ≤8/≥25

The maximum score is 20p. 
The score is evaluated as follows:
- 0-4p - low clinical risk
- 5-6p or <5 but individual parameter scoring 3 - medium clinical risk
- 7p or more - high clinical risk
en.misuse: Not be used in patients under 16 years of age and pregnant women.

gt0001.description: An assessment score used to determine the degree of illness of a patient and prompts critical care intervention.

gt0086.text: Emergency assessment by a clinical team/critical care outreach team with critical-care competencies and usually transfer of the patient to a higher dependency care area.

gt0087.text: Urgent review by a clinician skilled with competencies in the assessment of acute illness – usually a ward-based doctor or acute team nurse, who should consider whether escalation of care to a team with critical-care skills is required (ie critical care outreach team)

gt0088.text: A RED score refers to an extreme variation in a single physiological parameter is present (i.e., a score of 3 in any one physiological parameter).
